segment.source: User Account Control Group Policy and registry key settings (Windows 10)
segment.target: User Account Control Group Policy and registry key settings (Windows 10)

segment.source: Here's a list of UAC Group Policy and registry key settings that your organization can use to manage UAC.
segment.target: Here's a list of UAC Group Policy and registry key settings that your organization can use to manage UAC.

segment.source: User Account Control Group Policy and registry key settings
segment.target: User Account Control Group Policy and registry key settings

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Group Policy settings
segment.target: Group Policy settings

segment.source: There are 10 Group Policy settings that can be configured for User Account Control (UAC).
segment.target: There are 10 Group Policy settings that can be configured for User Account Control (UAC).

segment.source: The table lists the default for each of the policy settings, and the following sections explain the different UAC policy settings and provide recommendations.
segment.target: The table lists the default for each of the policy settings, and the following sections explain the different UAC policy settings and provide recommendations.

segment.source: These policy settings are located in Security SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options in the Local Security Policy snap-in.
segment.target: These policy settings are located in Security SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options in the Local Security Policy snap-in.

segment.source: For more information about each of the Group Policy settings, see the Group Policy description.
segment.target: For more information about each of the Group Policy settings, see the Group Policy description.

segment.source: For information about the registry key settings, see Registry key settings.
segment.target: For information about the registry key settings, see Registry key settings.

segment.source: Group Policy setting
segment.target: Group Policy setting

segment.source: Registry key
segment.target: Registry key

segment.source: Default
segment.target: Default

segment.source: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account
segment.target: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account

segment.source: FilterAdministratorToken
segment.target: FilterAdministratorToken

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop
segment.target: User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop

segment.source: EnableUIADesktopToggle
segment.target: EnableUIADesktopToggle

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode

segment.source: ConsentPromptBehaviorAdmin
segment.target: ConsentPromptBehaviorAdmin

segment.source: Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries
segment.target: Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries

segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users

segment.source: ConsentPromptBehaviorUser
segment.target: ConsentPromptBehaviorUser

segment.source: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop
segment.target: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop

segment.source: User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation

segment.source: EnableInstallerDetection
segment.target: EnableInstallerDetection

segment.source: Enabled (default for home)
segment.target: Enabled (default for home)

segment.source: Disabled (default for enterprise)
segment.target: Disabled (default for enterprise)

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated

segment.source: ValidateAdminCodeSignatures
segment.target: ValidateAdminCodeSignatures

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations

segment.source: EnableSecureUIAPaths
segment.target: EnableSecureUIAPaths

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode
segment.target: User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode

segment.source: EnableLUA
segment.target: EnableLUA

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation

segment.source: PromptOnSecureDesktop
segment.target: PromptOnSecureDesktop

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations
segment.target: User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations

segment.source: EnableVirtualization
segment.target: EnableVirtualization

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account
segment.target: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account

segment.source: The User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account policy setting controls the behavior of Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account policy setting controls the behavior of Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: The built-in Administrator account uses Admin Approval Mode.
segment.target: The built-in Administrator account uses Admin Approval Mode.

segment.source: By default, any operation that requires elevation of privilege will prompt the user to approve the operation.
segment.target: By default, any operation that requires elevation of privilege will prompt the user to approve the operation.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: (Default) The built-in Administrator account runs all applications with full administrative privilege.
segment.target: (Default) The built-in Administrator account runs all applications with full administrative privilege.

segment.source: User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop
segment.target: User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop

segment.source: The User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop policy setting controls whether User Interface Accessibility (UIAccess or UIA) programs can automatically disable the secure desktop for elevation prompts used by a standard user.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop policy setting controls whether User Interface Accessibility (UIAccess or UIA) programs can automatically disable the secure desktop for elevation prompts used by a standard user.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: UIA programs, including Windows Remote Assistance, automatically disable the secure desktop for elevation prompts.
segment.target: UIA programs, including Windows Remote Assistance, automatically disable the secure desktop for elevation prompts.

segment.source: If you do not disable the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting, the prompts appear on the interactive user's desktop instead of the secure desktop.
segment.target: If you do not disable the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting, the prompts appear on the interactive user's desktop instead of the secure desktop.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: (Default) The secure desktop can be disabled only by the user of the interactive desktop or by disabling the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting.
segment.target: (Default) The secure desktop can be disabled only by the user of the interactive desktop or by disabling the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting.

segment.source: UIA programs are designed to interact with Windows and application programs on behalf of a user.
segment.target: UIA programs are designed to interact with Windows and application programs on behalf of a user.

segment.source: This policy setting allows UIA programs to bypass the secure desktop to increase usability in certain cases; however, allowing elevation requests to appear on the interactive desktop instead of the secure desktop can increase your security risk.
segment.target: This policy setting allows UIA programs to bypass the secure desktop to increase usability in certain cases; however, allowing elevation requests to appear on the interactive desktop instead of the secure desktop can increase your security risk.

segment.source: UIA programs must be digitally signed because they must be able to respond to prompts regarding security issues, such as the UAC elevation prompt.
segment.target: UIA programs must be digitally signed because they must be able to respond to prompts regarding security issues, such as the UAC elevation prompt.

segment.source: By default, UIA programs are run only from the following protected paths:
segment.target: By default, UIA programs are run only from the following protected paths:

segment.source: ...Program Files, including subfolders
segment.target: ...Program Files, including subfolders

segment.source: ...Program Files (x86), including subfolders for 64-bit versions of Windows
segment.target: ...Program Files (x86), including subfolders for 64-bit versions of Windows

segment.source: ...WindowsSystem32
segment.target: ...WindowsSystem32

segment.source: The User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations policy setting disables the requirement to be run from a protected path.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations policy setting disables the requirement to be run from a protected path.

segment.source: While this policy setting applies to any UIA program, it is primarily used in certain remote assistance scenarios, including the Windows Remote Assistance program in Windows 7.
segment.target: While this policy setting applies to any UIA program, it is primarily used in certain remote assistance scenarios, including the Windows Remote Assistance program in Windows 7.

segment.source: If a user requests remote assistance from an administrator and the remote assistance session is established, any elevation prompts appear on the interactive user's secure desktop and the administrator's remote session is paused.
segment.target: If a user requests remote assistance from an administrator and the remote assistance session is established, any elevation prompts appear on the interactive user's secure desktop and the administrator's remote session is paused.

segment.source: To avoid pausing the remote administrator's session during elevation requests, the user may select the Allow IT Expert to respond to User Account Control prompts check box when setting up the remote assistance session.
segment.target: To avoid pausing the remote administrator's session during elevation requests, the user may select the Allow IT Expert to respond to User Account Control prompts check box when setting up the remote assistance session.

segment.source: However, selecting this check box requires that the interactive user respond to an elevation prompt on the secure desktop.
segment.target: However, selecting this check box requires that the interactive user respond to an elevation prompt on the secure desktop.

segment.source: If the interactive user is a standard user, the user does not have the required credentials to allow elevation.
segment.target: If the interactive user is a standard user, the user does not have the required credentials to allow elevation.

segment.source: If you enable this policy setting, requests for elevation are automatically sent to the interactive desktop (not the secure desktop) and also appear on the remote administrator's view of the desktop during a remote assistance session.
segment.target: If you enable this policy setting, requests for elevation are automatically sent to the interactive desktop (not the secure desktop) and also appear on the remote administrator's view of the desktop during a remote assistance session.

segment.source: This allows the remote administrator to provide the appropriate credentials for elevation.
segment.target: This allows the remote administrator to provide the appropriate credentials for elevation.

segment.source: This policy setting does not change the behavior of the UAC elevation prompt for administrators.
segment.target: This policy setting does not change the behavior of the UAC elevation prompt for administrators.

segment.source: If you plan to enable this policy setting, you should also review the effect of the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users policy setting.
segment.target: If you plan to enable this policy setting, you should also review the effect of the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users policy setting.

segment.source: If it is configured as Automatically deny elevation requests, elevation requests are not presented to the user.
segment.target: If it is configured as Automatically deny elevation requests, elevation requests are not presented to the user.

segment.source: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode
segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode

segment.source: The User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode policy setting controls the behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode policy setting controls the behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Elevate without prompting.
segment.target: Elevate without prompting.

segment.source: Allows privileged accounts to perform an operation that requires elevation without requiring consent or credentials.
segment.target: Allows privileged accounts to perform an operation that requires elevation without requiring consent or credentials.

segment.source: Note Use this option only in the most constrained environments.
segment.target: Note Use this option only in the most constrained environments.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop.
segment.target: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to enter a privileged user name and password.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to enter a privileged user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.

segment.source: Prompt for consent on the secure desktop.
segment.target: Prompt for consent on the secure desktop.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to select either Permit or Deny.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to select either Permit or Deny.

segment.source: If the user selects Permit, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.
segment.target: If the user selects Permit, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials.
segment.target: Prompt for credentials.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to enter an administrative user name and password.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to enter an administrative user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.

segment.source: Prompt for consent.
segment.target: Prompt for consent.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to select either Permit or Deny.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to select either Permit or Deny.

segment.source: If the user selects Permit, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.
segment.target: If the user selects Permit, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.

segment.source: Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries.
segment.target: Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries.

segment.source: (Default) When an operation for a non-Microsoft application requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to select either Permit or Deny.
segment.target: (Default) When an operation for a non-Microsoft application requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to select either Permit or Deny.

segment.source: If the user selects Permit, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.
segment.target: If the user selects Permit, the operation continues with the user's highest available privilege.

segment.source: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users
segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users

segment.source: The User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users policy setting controls the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users policy setting controls the behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Automatically deny elevation requests.
segment.target: Automatically deny elevation requests.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, a configurable access denied error message is displayed.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, a configurable access denied error message is displayed.

segment.source: An enterprise that is running desktops as standard user may choose this setting to reduce help desk calls.
segment.target: An enterprise that is running desktops as standard user may choose this setting to reduce help desk calls.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop.
segment.target: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop.

segment.source: (Default) When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to enter a different user name and password.
segment.target: (Default) When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted on the secure desktop to enter a different user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials.
segment.target: Prompt for credentials.

segment.source: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to enter an administrative user name and password.
segment.target: When an operation requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to enter an administrative user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.

segment.source: User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation

segment.source: The User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation policy setting controls the behavior of application installation detection for the computer.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation policy setting controls the behavior of application installation detection for the computer.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: (Default for home) When an application installation package is detected that requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to enter an administrative user name and password.
segment.target: (Default for home) When an application installation package is detected that requires elevation of privilege, the user is prompted to enter an administrative user name and password.

segment.source: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.
segment.target: If the user enters valid credentials, the operation continues with the applicable privilege.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: (Default for enterprise) Application installation packages are not detected and prompted for elevation.
segment.target: (Default for enterprise) Application installation packages are not detected and prompted for elevation.

segment.source: Enterprises that are running standard user desktops and use delegated installation technologies such as Group Policy Software Installation or Systems Management Server (SMS) should disable this policy setting.
segment.target: Enterprises that are running standard user desktops and use delegated installation technologies such as Group Policy Software Installation or Systems Management Server (SMS) should disable this policy setting.

segment.source: In this case, installer detection is unnecessary.
segment.target: In this case, installer detection is unnecessary.

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated

segment.source: The User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated policy setting enforces public key infrastructure (PKI) signature checks for any interactive applications that request elevation of privilege.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated policy setting enforces public key infrastructure (PKI) signature checks for any interactive applications that request elevation of privilege.

segment.source: Enterprise administrators can control which applications are allowed to run by adding certificates to the Trusted Publishers certificate store on local computers.
segment.target: Enterprise administrators can control which applications are allowed to run by adding certificates to the Trusted Publishers certificate store on local computers.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: Enforces the PKI certification path validation for a given executable file before it is permitted to run.
segment.target: Enforces the PKI certification path validation for a given executable file before it is permitted to run.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: (Default) Does not enforce PKI certification path validation before a given executable file is permitted to run.
segment.target: (Default) Does not enforce PKI certification path validation before a given executable file is permitted to run.

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations

segment.source: The User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations policy setting controls whether applications that request to run with a User Interface Accessibility (UIAccess) integrity level must reside in a secure location in the file system.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations policy setting controls whether applications that request to run with a User Interface Accessibility (UIAccess) integrity level must reside in a secure location in the file system.

segment.source: Secure locations are limited to the following:
segment.target: Secure locations are limited to the following:

segment.source: ...Program Files, including subfolders
segment.target: ...Program Files, including subfolders

segment.source: ...Windowssystem32
segment.target: ...Windowssystem32

segment.source: ...Program Files (x86), including subfolders for 64-bit versions of Windows
segment.target: ...Program Files (x86), including subfolders for 64-bit versions of Windows

segment.source: Note Windows enforces a PKI signature check on any interactive application that requests to run with a UIAccess integrity level regardless of the state of this security setting.
segment.target: Note Windows enforces a PKI signature check on any interactive application that requests to run with a UIAccess integrity level regardless of the state of this security setting.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: (Default) If an application resides in a secure location in the file system, it runs only with UIAccess integrity.
segment.target: (Default) If an application resides in a secure location in the file system, it runs only with UIAccess integrity.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: An application runs with UIAccess integrity even if it does not reside in a secure location in the file system.
segment.target: An application runs with UIAccess integrity even if it does not reside in a secure location in the file system.

segment.source: User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode
segment.target: User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode

segment.source: The User Account Control: Run all administrators Admin Approval Mode policy setting controls the behavior of all UAC policy settings for the computer.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Run all administrators Admin Approval Mode policy setting controls the behavior of all UAC policy settings for the computer.

segment.source: If you change this policy setting, you must restart your computer.
segment.target: If you change this policy setting, you must restart your computer.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: (Default) Admin Approval Mode is enabled.
segment.target: (Default) Admin Approval Mode is enabled.

segment.source: This policy must be enabled and related UAC policy settings must also be set appropriately to allow the built-in Administrator account and all other users who are members of the Administrators group to run in Admin Approval Mode.
segment.target: This policy must be enabled and related UAC policy settings must also be set appropriately to allow the built-in Administrator account and all other users who are members of the Administrators group to run in Admin Approval Mode.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: Admin Approval Mode and all related UAC policy settings are disabled.
segment.target: Admin Approval Mode and all related UAC policy settings are disabled.

segment.source: Note If this policy setting is disabled, the Security Center notifies you that the overall security of the operating system has been reduced.
segment.target: Note If this policy setting is disabled, the Security Center notifies you that the overall security of the operating system has been reduced.

segment.source: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation

segment.source: The User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting controls whether the elevation request prompt is displayed on the interactive user's desktop or the secure desktop.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting controls whether the elevation request prompt is displayed on the interactive user's desktop or the secure desktop.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: (Default) All elevation requests go to the secure desktop regardless of prompt behavior policy settings for administrators and standard users.
segment.target: (Default) All elevation requests go to the secure desktop regardless of prompt behavior policy settings for administrators and standard users.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: All elevation requests go to the interactive user's desktop.
segment.target: All elevation requests go to the interactive user's desktop.

segment.source: Prompt behavior policy settings for administrators and standard users are used.
segment.target: Prompt behavior policy settings for administrators and standard users are used.

segment.source: When this policy setting is enabled, it overrides the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode policy setting.
segment.target: When this policy setting is enabled, it overrides the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode policy setting.

segment.source: The following table describes the behavior of the elevation prompt for each of the administrator policy settings when the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting is enabled or disabled.
segment.target: The following table describes the behavior of the elevation prompt for each of the administrator policy settings when the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting is enabled or disabled.

segment.source: Administrator policy setting
segment.target: Administrator policy setting

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop
segment.target: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: Prompt for consent on the secure desktop
segment.target: Prompt for consent on the secure desktop

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.target: Prompt for credentials

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.

segment.source: Prompt for consent
segment.target: Prompt for consent

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.

segment.source: Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries
segment.target: Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.

segment.source: When this policy setting is enabled, it overrides the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users policy setting.
segment.target: When this policy setting is enabled, it overrides the User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users policy setting.

segment.source: The following table describes the behavior of the elevation prompt for each of the standard user policy settings when the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting is enabled or disabled.
segment.target: The following table describes the behavior of the elevation prompt for each of the standard user policy settings when the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation policy setting is enabled or disabled.

segment.source: Standard policy setting
segment.target: Standard policy setting

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Automatically deny elevation requests
segment.target: Automatically deny elevation requests

segment.source: No prompt.
segment.target: No prompt.

segment.source: The request is automatically denied.
segment.target: The request is automatically denied.

segment.source: No prompt.
segment.target: No prompt.

segment.source: The request is automatically denied.
segment.target: The request is automatically denied.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop
segment.target: Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials
segment.target: Prompt for credentials

segment.source: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.
segment.target: The prompt appears on the interactive user's desktop.

segment.source: User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations
segment.target: User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations

segment.source: The User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations policy setting controls whether application write failures are redirected to defined registry and file system locations.
segment.target: The User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations policy setting controls whether application write failures are redirected to defined registry and file system locations.

segment.source: This policy setting mitigates applications that run as administrator and write run-time application data to %ProgramFiles%, %Windir%, %Windir%system32, or HKLMSoftware.
segment.target: This policy setting mitigates applications that run as administrator and write run-time application data to %ProgramFiles%, %Windir%, %Windir%system32, or HKLMSoftware.

segment.source: The options are:
segment.target: The options are:

segment.source: Enabled.
segment.target: Enabled.

segment.source: (Default) Application write failures are redirected at run time to defined user locations for both the file system and registry.
segment.target: (Default) Application write failures are redirected at run time to defined user locations for both the file system and registry.

segment.source: Disabled.
segment.target: Disabled.

segment.source: Applications that write data to protected locations fail.
segment.target: Applications that write data to protected locations fail.

segment.source: Registry key settings
segment.target: Registry key settings

segment.source: The registry keys are found in HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionPoliciesSystem.
segment.target: The registry keys are found in HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftWindowsCurrentVersionPoliciesSystem.

segment.source: For information about each of the registry keys, see the associated Group Policy description.
segment.target: For information about each of the registry keys, see the associated Group Policy description.

segment.source: Registry key
segment.target: Registry key

segment.source: Group Policy setting
segment.target: Group Policy setting

segment.source: Registry setting
segment.target: Registry setting

segment.source: FilterAdministratorToken
segment.target: FilterAdministratorToken

segment.source: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account
segment.target: User Account Control: Admin Approval Mode for the built-in Administrator account

segment.source: 0 (Default) = Disabled
segment.target: 0 (Default) = Disabled

segment.source: 1 = Enabled
segment.target: 1 = Enabled

segment.source: EnableUIADesktopToggle
segment.target: EnableUIADesktopToggle

segment.source: User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop
segment.target: User Account Control: Allow UIAccess applications to prompt for elevation without using the secure desktop

segment.source: 0 (Default) = Disabled
segment.target: 0 (Default) = Disabled

segment.source: 1 = Enabled
segment.target: 1 = Enabled

segment.source: ConsentPromptBehaviorAdmin
segment.target: ConsentPromptBehaviorAdmin

segment.source: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode
segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators in Admin Approval Mode

segment.source: 0 = Elevate without prompting
segment.target: 0 = Elevate without prompting

segment.source: 1 = Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop
segment.target: 1 = Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop

segment.source: 2 = Prompt for consent on the secure desktop
segment.target: 2 = Prompt for consent on the secure desktop

segment.source: 3 = Prompt for credentials
segment.target: 3 = Prompt for credentials

segment.source: 4 = Prompt for consent
segment.target: 4 = Prompt for consent

segment.source: 5 (Default) = Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries
segment.target: 5 (Default) = Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries

segment.source: ConsentPromptBehaviorUser
segment.target: ConsentPromptBehaviorUser

segment.source: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users
segment.target: User Account Control: Behavior of the elevation prompt for standard users

segment.source: 0 = Automatically deny elevation requests
segment.target: 0 = Automatically deny elevation requests

segment.source: 1 = Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop
segment.target: 1 = Prompt for credentials on the secure desktop

segment.source: 3 (Default) = Prompt for credentials
segment.target: 3 (Default) = Prompt for credentials

segment.source: EnableInstallerDetection
segment.target: EnableInstallerDetection

segment.source: User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Detect application installations and prompt for elevation

segment.source: 1 = Enabled (default for home)
segment.target: 1 = Enabled (default for home)

segment.source: 0 = Disabled (default for enterprise)
segment.target: 0 = Disabled (default for enterprise)

segment.source: ValidateAdminCodeSignatures
segment.target: ValidateAdminCodeSignatures

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated

segment.source: 0 (Default) = Disabled
segment.target: 0 (Default) = Disabled

segment.source: 1 = Enabled
segment.target: 1 = Enabled

segment.source: EnableSecureUIAPaths
segment.target: EnableSecureUIAPaths

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate UIAccess applications that are installed in secure locations

segment.source: 0 = Disabled
segment.target: 0 = Disabled

segment.source: 1 (Default) = Enabled
segment.target: 1 (Default) = Enabled

segment.source: EnableLUA
segment.target: EnableLUA

segment.source: User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode
segment.target: User Account Control: Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode

segment.source: 0 = Disabled
segment.target: 0 = Disabled

segment.source: 1 (Default) = Enabled
segment.target: 1 (Default) = Enabled

segment.source: PromptOnSecureDesktop
segment.target: PromptOnSecureDesktop

segment.source: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation

segment.source: 0 = Disabled
segment.target: 0 = Disabled

segment.source: 1 (Default) = Enabled
segment.target: 1 (Default) = Enabled

segment.source: EnableVirtualization
segment.target: EnableVirtualization

segment.source: User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations
segment.target: User Account Control: Virtualize file and registry write failures to per-user locations

segment.source: 0 = Disabled
segment.target: 0 = Disabled

segment.source: 1 (Default) = Enabled
segment.target: 1 (Default) = Enabled
